utterances: How does this money change anything for you?
Are you going to continue to work?
What do you do now?
I've been doing a bit of voice over and web design and struggling at it.
I - you know, at any rate, it's - what the money means to me - and it's not about the money.
I think to focus on the money is to trivialize it a little bit, what actually happened.
The money allows me to continue to do the things that I like to do - doing the teaching in the juvenile hall, speaking out against the death penalty and, you know, enjoying the rest of my life.
I mean, I had a big chunk taken out of the middle.
I have to make every minute count, is how I view it.
And, you know, it does give me that luxury.
And I'm thankful for that.
But I think the acknowledgment is what I am more grateful for.
Bruce Lisker served 26 years in prison for a crime he did not commit.
He was released in 2009, received a $7 million settlement this past week.
Bruce, thanks so much for talking with us.
Thank you, Rachel.
The arrest of a Chinese tech executive adds to her company's contentious relationship with the U.S.
Meng Wanzhou is chief financial officer of Huawei and daughter of the founder.
She was arrested in Canada on a U.S.
extradition request.
NPR's Jasmine Garsd reports on the history of the company.
Ren Zhengfei is a former People's Liberation Army officer who founded the telecommunications company in 1987.
Since then, the company has grown into a worldwide juggernaut.
It expects to ring up more than $100 billion in sales this year.
Sarah Cook is a senior research analyst for East Asia at Freedom House, a democracy watchdog organization.
Chinese technology companies generally, and particularly these tech giants - their success or failure isn't accidental.
It's really contingent upon government support.
Those ties between Huawei's founder and the Chinese government have raised questions about potential espionage dangers for the U.S., which Huawei has repeatedly denied.
But Cook says the concerns are hardly outlandish.
It's hard to imagine that a company like Huawei would not provide information to Chinese intelligence agencies if it was requested.
It's hard to imagine that they would have a choice, even.
Earlier this year, U.S.
intelligence agencies warned American citizens against using products and services made by Huawei and another Chinese company, ZTE.
Around the same time, AT&T backed out of selling Huawei's smartphones.
The U.S.
government isn't alone in its concern about Huawei and Chinese espionage.
Australia has banned Huawei for the next generation of cellphone networks.
In addition to espionage concerns, Huawei has been suspected of shipping products to Iran despite American sanctions.
And that's reportedly why Meng Wanzhou was arrested earlier this week, although the charges have not been publicly disclosed.
The Chinese government has demanded she be released.
Jasmine Garsd, NPR News, New York.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Tony Cox, in for Farai Chideya.
Welcome to the first day of summer.
Coming up, we've got a quite a show for you today, including Senator Chris Dodd on a bill he hoped will help solve some longstanding Civil Rights era murders.
And we've got Dr. Ro kicking off summer with some healthy heart eating tips.
But first, let's go to the headlines.
Today we start in New Orleans where the Army Corps of Engineers says some neighborhoods could still see as much as eight feet of flooding if another big storm hits.
Among the hardest hit would be parts of the city's northern Gentilly and Lakeview neighborhoods.
With that said, the Corps insist New Orleans, on a whole, is far better prepared for a one in 400 chance of storm, like Katrina, than it was two years ago.
And that, they say, is because of improvements the Corps has made to the Big Easy's dated levee system.
Our second headline takes us to Washington, D.C.
where the head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division testifies today.
Wan Kim is set to answer questions from the Senate Judiciary Committee about reports that his department's become increasingly politicized.
The Washington Post also ran a piece today on the man Kim replaced, Bradley Schlozman.
You may remember, he testified before the same committee earlier this month and admitted that he had boasted about hiring Republican lawyers.
Now, the Post reports that at least three minority women lawyers were transferred out of the division because Schlozman questioned their political loyalties.
Today he denies taking any improper action against any division attorney.
British Prime Minister Theresa May has secured her Cabinet's approval for a draft Brexit agreement with the European Union - well, most of her Cabinet.
Within the last few hours, her Brexit minister Dominic Raab quit, saying he could not support the deal.
So did a second Cabinet minister and a couple of other top officials who are just outside the Cabinet.
We don't know how much farther this is going to go.
Integrity.
What would you do when the boss is not looking?
What would you do when you don't have to come in a certain time, and you don't have to leave?
You don't have to clock in or clock out.
Would you go home and go to sleep for three or four hours, or would you just be on the job about your father's business?
So integrity is a big thing to me, and I believe that when nobody is watching, God is watching.
After Baldwin completed the program, Jobs Partnership placed him with Steven Koon's(ph) small recycling company.
He began as a driver, moving around carpet underlay.
Now, he's a salesman.
I think I started Allen at $7.00 an hour four or five years ago, and if he does what he has the capability to do, he'll make $70,000 this year.
Koon says he didn't care about Baldwin's skill or education or his past.

If a person tells me that they have made a change in their life, and they have put Jesus Christ as the pillar of their life, then I know I don't have to be in the building for things to go the right way, because they have someone greater than me to be accountable to.
I asked Koon if he's hired other from the program.
That's been my only encounter, although, Mark, I need a couple of great Spanish-speaking guys.
I need somebody right away.
Do you have one?
Absolutely.
We've got plenty of folks.
We just graduated two classes, most of them Latino, bilingual.
That's perfect.
That man in the corner of the room is Mark Stanakis, executive director of Jobs Partnership in Orlando.
Later, I raised some questions.
Does his program appeal to companies that do not buy into Evangelical Christianity?
He says so far, about a third of the companies have no religious motivation.
Do graduates still have a job, say, five years after they leave the program?
Stanakis doesn't know.
He's just hired someone to track that down.
And since nearly 40 percent of the program's budget comes from the state or federal government, are they using taxpayer money to convert people?
Here Stanikas is adamant--money from the federal faith-based initiative goes towards secular lessons and staffing, he says.
The spiritual content is taught by volunteers.

Now, we understand that folks that sit through the training and are beginning to be exposed to the Bible and the principles that we're teaching, there probably will be a change, some type of spiritual transformation that takes place.
And we're certainly are not going to stop that.
But our theology is that God is the one that's in control of bringing people into a relationship with him.
It's not our responsibility to do that.
Stanikas says it's surprisingly easy to find jobs for his graduates.
With a 3 percent unemployment rate in Orlando, he says companies are desperate for workers trained in soft skills.
Once they start hiring from us, they keep coming back.
Because they're like, why would I go to a newspaper ad when I can hire from you?
That's what Florida Hospital told him.
In the past five years, they've hired 35 graduates.
Judy Bond, who heads up Human Resources, says the hospital had a terrible turnover problem, especially at the entry-level positions.
She began hiring people from Jobs Partnership and training them in the language and practice of medicine.
And then when they graduated, they had the soft skills and also the educational skills that were needed to work on this unit.
And we've seen so many of these students not just stop with this position, because they're in the hospital, they're working with doctors and nurses, and they become inspired.
She says three out of four of the hires from Jobs Partnership have gone on to get more training--becoming nurses, for example, or sonogram technicians.
Ms.
NIKISHA OLDEN(ph) (Florida Hospital technician): Okay, I'm going to check your monitors, okay?
Okay.
Nikisha Olden joined Florida Hospital as a hospital assistant 16 months ago.
You get comfortable.
Not too long before that, she lived in subsidized housing, unmarried with two children.
She has a mental picture of her low point: manning the cash register at Wal-Mart, earning $7.00 an hour, with a long line snaking in front of her.
I mean, my foot be hurting, legs be hurting, your back be hurting.
You have to stand a long time, and it's like, for this little bitty paycheck.
That's it.
You know?
It's like...something got to give.
The Public Housing Office suggested she try Jobs Partnership to move her off public assistance.
Olden had doubts, but she stuck it out.
I asked Olden, who is not particularly churchgoing, what was the seminal moment of the program, and she recalls a talk about going the extra mile.
